ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of intermediate Chinese vocabulary, and I also got a lot of practice in reading and writing characters as well as speaking.
Learned Chinese vocabulary for reading and writing, grammar, and some aspects of Chinese culture.

I greatly improved my writing and grammar skills, and gained greater proficiency in stringing together different grammar structures that I may have heard or used before at home but did not truly understand how to use properly. I also learned a lot about various aspects of Chinese culture and history that I didn't think about before.

My character writing and speaking skills improved greatly, and my knowledge of vocabulary and grammar has increased. I feel more comfortable speaking in Chinese and also am able to read and write more sentences than before.

As a heritage speaker who had experience with speaking and reading but practically zero experience with pinyin and writing Chinese characters, at first I was nervous about whether I would be able to catch up (I tested into the course). Looking back, I learned so much from this courseand made up for my weaker areas in just a semester.
chinese vocab, speaking, writing
A better understanding of the Chinese language, primarily improving my reading, writing, and speaking skills
Lots of Chinese characters, grammar, and history/culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course was the quality of the professor and the content of the course. Most if not all of the faculty in the Chinese department are highly regarded for good reason, and the lessons and vocab that they teach us are usually useful and relevant. The work assigned in the class also is productive towards learning and improving your Chinese.
The course is great, very organized and there is good correlation between your grade and actual learning.

The strengths of this course are that it is very structured and I know what to expect every day when I walk into class. There is a great variety of reading, writing, speaking, and listening exercises, and I like the addition of the asynchronous day. I think the course could be improved through more group and partner activities/work to create a stronger class bond.

Strength: I like how the class was taught in units, which made it very easy to digest. Unit tests as opposed to midterms/finals were also helpful. Chen Laoshi is also so supportive! It's a course where if you really put in the effort, you will succeed.  
Weakness: I was surprised by the lack of opportunities for collaboration/class interaction in the first half of the semester. The final project at the end of the semester was great and seemed to really connect our class, but I wish there had been more collaborative projects/opportunities earlier on in the semester.

strengths: consistency, workload

weakness: constantly changing schedule is disruptive, especially the quizzes. 
I found the tutoring sessions outside of class to be redundant and pointless, especially considering all the resources that are alrdy available. I didnt feel that it added to my learning, rather just increased the workload and wasted time. I would recommend making tutoring optional for those who need it.
This class was very engaging. I was provided with a lot of opportunities to improve my Chinese skills both during and outside of class.
Very clear structure and well-organized format. Good pacing and conducive to learning Chinese.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any heritage speakers. They do a great job of focusing on the reading and writing skills that a lot of us lack, and don't spend an excessive amount of time on our speaking skills.
Yes, Chinese is a really useful language to learn. It is definitely a class where the amount of work you put in directly translates to results in both grades and in learning.
I would highly recommend this course to another student because my professor was very kind and student-focused, and even though there is a higher workload I gained a lot from this course.

Anyone looking to improve their Chinese or engage with Chinese culture should definitely take this class. The class is designed especially for heritage speakers, and takes advantage of our previous knowledge / abilities, so the course is more fast paced.

Yes! I never thought I'd like language learning (there goes 4 years of Spanish) until I took this course. Chen Laoshi is the bestsupportive, understanding, kind, and passionate. 10/10 would recommend this class, especially if Chen Laoshi is teaching it.
yes because it is intensive
Yes, if you want to significantly improve your Chinese skills, this is a great class to take.
Absolutely! Learned so so much, so quickly, in such a supportive learning environment.
Absolutely, if you're on the heritage Chinese track.
